NEWS-LETTER

120 Engineers Dr. Kraushaar,
Attend Dance. Goucher Club
At Assembly
By AL STALLKNECHT
Due to a tine promotional program by John Holmes and the
members of the Engineers' Control
Board; the Engineers' Dance, to
be held tomorrow night at the
Greenway Apartments, has been
listed as a complete sell-out.
Holmes announced that the
maximum limit of 60 tickets had
been sold a week ago and further
sales were not 'contemplated so
that overcrowding would not occur.
Ticket sales have been limited
to members of the Engineering
School, so, in effect, the first truly
closed engineer's dance in many
years has resulted.
Holmes added that setups will
be available at cost price, and that
the dance is scheduled to run from
9 to 1.

‘'ector Out
Frank Kaisler, Editor-in-Chief
of the engineering periodical, The
Vector, announced that the distribution of the year's first Vector
Issue would he accomplished this
week.
Bob Beta, circulation manager,
has supervised the distribution to
alumni and undergraduate subscription holders and has announced that individual copies
are available at 25 cents per issue.
New Plan
The 16 page periodical has as
Its featured article a treatise on
the effects of the Hopkins Plan on
the Engineering School. a subject
heretofore virtually untouched by
campus literature.
The co-authors, Ferd Leink uhler and Aemonn MeGeady, used
information from personal interviews with the several department.
heads of the Engineering .School
for the observations and conclusions presented in the article.
Kaisler expressed optimism over
the reception of this first issue by
engineering students. He stated
that emphasis had been placed on
the quality of the art work, degree of news coverage, and interest of feature articles in the
formation of this issue of the periodical.

Continuing its policy of "bigger
and better assemblies for the Hopkins", the Student Council will
sponsor an expanded version of
the annual Christmas Assembly
next Friday morning at ten in the
gym.
• The Hopkins and Goucher Glee
Clubs will present a joint program
and Dr. Otto Kraushaar, president
of Goucher College, will speak.
He will be introduced by President
Bronk who will give the official
season's greeting to the University.
The joint concert., the first in
several years, will feature "Unto
Us a Child is Born" from Bach's
cantata number 142. Osmar P.
Steinwald, Director of Student
Music at Hopkins, and Dr. James
Allen Dash, director of the Goucher Glee Club will direct.
Mr. Stein wald expressed the
hope that the joint concert would
become an annual affair.
He also said that there is a possibility that station WBAL will
transcribe the program for a rebroadcast sometime during the

for the advancement or Spanish
and Portugese languages, literature and history with a world wide
membership limited to 100 persons.
Since Dr. Salinas always wrote
in Spanish, presentations in this
country are in various English
translations, none of them his own.
Most of his poetry has been translated by Miss Eleanor L. Turnbull.
He was 59 years old at the time
of his death and had been ill for
two months.
He is survived by his wife, Margarita, a daughter, Mrs. Solede
Marichal, wife of a professor of
Spanish Literature at Harvard,
and his son, Jaime.

Christmas Party
Planned At Dorm
Dorm students Will hold their
Christmas party Friday, December
14, in the .Cotnmons Room of the
dorm from nine till one, Robert
Markus, president of the DSRC
announced.
There

will

be

no

admission

charge to dorm students and their
dates. A talent show and caroling
will be featured, followed by
dancing later in the evening. Refreshments will be served.
Th program is one of three big
events on the DSRC's entertainment schedule. A dance held at
Halloween was the first, and another dance is planned for around
St. Patrick's Day.

campus will go from a six to a

are not used enough to make staying open practical.

WHAT'S SO DIFFERENT
ABOUT ENGLEWOOD, N. J.?
In Englewood, the local telephone exchange looks pretty much
like the telephone building in any other town.
And Englewood's telephones seem just the same as the twentyseven million other dial telephones in the country.
But there's a difference ...
You can pick up a telephone in Englewood and dial San Francisco
telephone numbers direct!
In fact, you can dial any one of eleven million telephone numbers
in thirteen widely- scattered areas from coast to coast.

THE CRY GOES OUT
Every year the cry goes out and we
are asked:"What would
the Hopkins be like without the YT"
The.question demands an
obvious answer.
Most of the campus activities use
Levering without charge.
Direct and indirect benefits are derived
from the fact that
it has become the tradition and cultural
center at Homewood.
These functions are an expensive business.
Annually, the Y
Commission initiates a membership drive to
partially cover this
deficit. Thus far, their efforts have met with
little success.
The fault does mit lie entirely with the student.
By its very
nature, the Y and most of its functions are taken
for granted.
The Commission has not placed sufficient emphasis
behind its
drive to overcome this general indifference.
For many years it has spread the appeal over an
extended
period of time instead of concentrating its efforts into a
short,
decisive campaign.
It is hoped that at it meeting this afternoon, the Commission,
under a president who has used emphasis with repeated effectiveness, will take steps to correct these important omissions..

Eagerly looking forward to
their first scrimmage, with Park
School here on December 14 at
4:30 p.m., the frosh hoopsters
have been working hard to round
into form.
Coach
Mac Erwin had his
charges competing in three man
scrimmages in the early part of
the week; later full court scrimmages were begun to simulate
game conditions. Erwin is concentrating on the weave for his scoring punch, while the switching
man to man will be employed on
the defense. Both should, be quite
effective once the season gets
under way.
The coach is still uncertain as
to who his starting five will be,
but several cagers have shown up
well in the scrimmages thus far.
Two forwards, Lowell Wilson
and John Dmytrush, look good.
They are fast, shifty, and drive
hard. Both around 5-10, they
handle themselves well on the defense also.
Dave Hack at 6-4 is the big man
on the yearling Jay squad. An excellent rebounder, he is effective
anywhere inside of the foul line.
Guards Ed Haberman and Ty
Freeman, both over 6 feet, have
shown skill in hitting the cords
from the outside. Good passing
and ball handling have also been
exhibited by these two.
Coach Erwin seemed pleased at
the progress of the squad so far.
He feels that by the time the first
game, with Calvert Hall here on
January 5 at 7 p.m., arrives he
Will have a team worthy of wearing the black and blue.

Klemmick has been slowed down
by a knee injury sustained during the football season.

Dave Gipe, the transfer. from
Pittsburgh -J.C., drew high praise
from Coach Turner. "He's improving all the time", he said, "He'll
certainly make himself felt. He
has a good outside shot."
Bob Schapiro and Irwin Kelson
round out the squad. Neither
played intercollegiate ball last
year.

reports of Loyola, Hopkins' traditional opponent. The Hounds
will be taller and therefore tougher than last year. Western Maryland has almost its entire squad
back, including set-shot sensation
Art Press.

120 Engineers Dr. Kraushaar,
Attend Dance. Goucher Club
At Assembly
By AL STALLKNECHT
Due to a tine promotional program by John Holmes and the
members of the Engineers' Control
Board; the Engineers' Dance, to
be held tomorrow night at the
Greenway Apartments, has been
listed as a complete sell-out.
Holmes announced that the
maximum limit of 60 tickets had
been sold a week ago and further
sales were not 'contemplated so
that overcrowding would not occur.
Ticket sales have been limited
to members of the Engineering
School, so, in effect, the first truly
closed engineer's dance in many
years has resulted.
Holmes added that setups will
be available at cost price, and that
the dance is scheduled to run from
9 to 1.

‘'ector Out
Frank Kaisler, Editor-in-Chief
of the engineering periodical, The
Vector, announced that the distribution of the year's first Vector
Issue would he accomplished this
week.
Bob Beta, circulation manager,
has supervised the distribution to
alumni and undergraduate subscription holders and has announced that individual copies
are available at 25 cents per issue.
New Plan
The 16 page periodical has as
Its featured article a treatise on
the effects of the Hopkins Plan on
the Engineering School. a subject
heretofore virtually untouched by
campus literature.
The co-authors, Ferd Leink uhler and Aemonn MeGeady, used
information from personal interviews with the several department.
heads of the Engineering .School
for the observations and conclusions presented in the article.
Kaisler expressed optimism over
the reception of this first issue by
engineering students. He stated
that emphasis had been placed on
the quality of the art work, degree of news coverage, and interest of feature articles in the
formation of this issue of the periodical.

Continuing its policy of "bigger
and better assemblies for the Hopkins", the Student Council will
sponsor an expanded version of
the annual Christmas Assembly
next Friday morning at ten in the
gym.
• The Hopkins and Goucher Glee
Clubs will present a joint program
and Dr. Otto Kraushaar, president
of Goucher College, will speak.
He will be introduced by President
Bronk who will give the official
season's greeting to the University.
The joint concert., the first in
several years, will feature "Unto
Us a Child is Born" from Bach's
cantata number 142. Osmar P.
Steinwald, Director of Student
Music at Hopkins, and Dr. James
Allen Dash, director of the Goucher Glee Club will direct.
Mr. Stein wald expressed the
hope that the joint concert would
become an annual affair.
He also said that there is a possibility that station WBAL will
transcribe the program for a rebroadcast sometime during the

Spanish Literature at Harvard,
and his son, Jaime.

announced.

will

no

charge to dorm students and their

You can pick up a telephone in Englewood and dial San Francisco

In fact, you can dial any one of eleven million telephone numbers
in thirteen widely- scattered areas from coast to coast.

THE CRY GOES OUT
Every year the cry goes out and we
are asked:"What would
the Hopkins be like without the YT"
The.question demands an
obvious answer.
Most of the campus activities use
Levering without charge.
Direct and indirect benefits are derived
from the fact that
it has become the tradition and cultural
center at Homewood.
These functions are an expensive business.
Annually, the Y
Commission initiates a membership drive to
partially cover this
deficit. Thus far, their efforts have met with
little success.
The fault does mit lie entirely with the student.
By its very
nature, the Y and most of its functions are taken
for granted.
The Commission has not placed sufficient emphasis
behind its
drive to overcome this general indifference.
For many years it has spread the appeal over an
extended
period of time instead of concentrating its efforts into a
short,
decisive campaign.
It is hoped that at it meeting this afternoon, the Commission,
under a president who has used emphasis with repeated effectiveness, will take steps to correct these important omissions..

Frosh Meet Carnegie Tech Addition
To
Park Dec. 14 Jay 70th Anniversary Slate

Eagerly looking forward to
their first scrimmage, with Park
School here on December 14 at
4:30 p.m., the frosh hoopsters
have been working hard to round
into form.
Coach
Mac Erwin had his
charges competing in three man
scrimmages in the early part of
the week; later full court scrimmages were begun to simulate
game conditions. Erwin is concentrating on the weave for his scoring punch, while the switching
man to man will be employed on
the defense. Both should, be quite
effective once the season gets
under way.
The coach is still uncertain as
to who his starting five will be,
but several cagers have shown up
well in the scrimmages thus far.
Two forwards, Lowell Wilson
and John Dmytrush, look good.
They are fast, shifty, and drive
hard. Both around 5-10, they
handle themselves well on the defense also.
Dave Hack at 6-4 is the big man
on the yearling Jay squad. An excellent rebounder, he is effective
anywhere inside of the foul line.
Guards Ed Haberman and Ty
Freeman, both over 6 feet, have
shown skill in hitting the cords
from the outside. Good passing
and ball handling have also been
exhibited by these two.
Coach Erwin seemed pleased at
the progress of the squad so far.
He feels that by the time the first
game, with Calvert Hall here on
January 5 at 7 p.m., arrives he
Will have a team worthy of wearing the black and blue.

Five members of last year's
freshman squad have achieved
varsity status. Six-foot two-inch
Bob Evans has looked very good,
according to Turner, especially in
his .rebound work. Possibly the
greatest improvement has been
shown by Al Birtch. Angie Fortunato and Howie Schwartz have
also impressed Turner. George
Klemmick has been slowed down
by a knee injury sustained during the football season.
Gipe Good
Dave Gipe, the transfer. from
Pittsburgh -J.C., drew high praise
from Coach Turner. "He's improving all the time", he said, "He'll
certainly make himself felt. He
has a good outside shot."
Bob Schapiro and Irwin Kelson
round out the squad. Neither
played intercollegiate ball last
year.
Turner has heard only scattered
reports of Loyola, Hopkins' traditional opponent. The Hounds
will be taller and therefore tougher than last year. Western Maryland has almost its entire squad
back, including set-shot sensation
Art Press.

Smith Moans
Injury Blues
As the varsity wrestling squad
entered its final week of training
before its opening meet next Friday, Coach Freddie Smith was
still looking for grapplers to fill
his two heavier weight classes.
At the present time Smith has
but one heavyweight, Bob Pedric,
and he has no previous wrestling
experience. In the 177 pound atlas
there also is only one grappler,
Bill Levy. An injury to. either or
both of these key men would render the Jays helpless.
Outside of these two vieighto
the team shapes up very strongly.
Adam Syczypinski, who started
the season at 157, has switched
to 167. This gives the varsity two
strong men in Syczypinski and
Dave Crook, varsity end.
